Introduction

Japanese encephalitis is a preventable, mosquito-borne viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), a member of the Flaviviridae family.  It is the leading cause of viral encephalitis in Asia and the western Pacific.  Although most infections are asymptomatic, a small percentage progress to severe neuroinvasive disease, which can be fatal or result in permanent neurologic sequelae.  Prevention with vaccination and mosquito control measures can reduce infection rates.

Pathogenesis



JEV is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus belonging to the Flaviviridae family.  JEV is transmitted primarily by Culex mosquitoes (especially Culex tritaeniorhynchus).  The virus replicates in various hosts, primarily pigs and wading birds, and is passed to mosquitoes during feeding.  Viral accumulation occurs in mosquito salivary glands, and a bite from an infected female mosquito can lead to human transmission.



After inoculation, the virus replicates in local tissues and regional lymph nodes.  In most cases, the immune system contains the infection.  In some individuals, however, the virus crosses the blood-brain barrier and infects neurons.  The thalamus, basal ganglia, brainstem, hippocampus, and spinal cord are common sites of involvement.  Neuronal damage occurs due to both direct viral cytotoxicity and immune-mediated injury.

Risk factors



Japanese encephalitis is endemic in many parts of Asia and the western Pacific, particularly in rural or agricultural regions where Culex mosquitoes breed in rice paddies and stagnant water.  Peak incidence coincides with increased mosquito activity during monsoon season or rainy months.  Risk factors for disease include young age (<15) and lack of prior immunization.  Travelers to endemic areas are also at risk if unvaccinated (particularly if traveling for a prolonged period of time during transmission season and spending time in rural regions).

Clinical presentation



The incubation period for JEV is usually about a week, and mosquito exposure in the endemic area is often known.  Most individuals infected with JEV remain asymptomatic or, less commonly, have mild symptoms of viral illness (eg, fever, headache).  When severe disease does occur (<1% of cases), it typically begins with a prodromal phase characterized by sudden onset of nonspecific symptoms including fever, headache, malaise, and vomiting, which typically last for several days.  The encephalitis phase follows and is characterized by:



  • Altered mental status (eg, confusion, disorientation, acute psychosis).
  • Seizures (often generalized tonic-clonic), especially in children.
  • Focal neurologic deficits (eg, hemiparesis or cranial nerve palsies).
  • Extrapyramidal (Parkinsonian) symptoms (eg tremor, rigidity, and abnormal posturing due to basal ganglia involvement).


Increased intracranial pressure and brainstem involvement may lead to respiratory failure.  In some cases, flaccid paralysis may occur due to anterior horn cell involvement, similar to poliomyelitis.

Diagnosis



Patients with encephalitis are often evaluated with lumbar puncture, neuroimaging (usually MRI of the brain), and electroencephalography.  Diagnosis is supported by laboratory and imaging findings in endemic regions:



  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:  Typically reveals a viral pattern with lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal to mildly elevated protein, and normal glucose levels.  Elevated opening pressure is often present as well.
  • JEV-specific IgM antibodies:  Diagnostic in CSF.  Serum IgM antibodies can be helpful in the appropriate clinical context but may also be positive in patients with asymptomatic infection or recent vaccination.
  • MRI of the brain:  May show nonspecific bilateral T2 hyperintensities in the thalami, basal ganglia, midbrain, and hippocampus.
  • EEG:  May demonstrate nonspecific, generalized slowing or epileptiform discharges consistent with diffuse cerebral dysfunction.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of Japanese encephalitis includes other viral and nonviral causes of encephalitis, seizures, and acute flaccid paralysis:



  • Herpes simplex virus:  Commonly causes sporadic encephalitis; it is characterized by confusion, focal neurologic deficits, and seizures.  MRI often shows abnormalities in the temporal lobes, and CSF usually shows elevated erythrocytes (in addition to lymphocytic pleocytosis).
  • Cryptococcus neoformans:  Can cause meningoencephalitis.  The vast majority of infections occur in individuals with severe immunosuppression (eg, advanced AIDS).  Most patients have a slowly progressive headache, lethargy, personality changes, and memory impairment.
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome:  Presents with progressive and symmetric ascending paralysis, paresthesias, decreased to absent reflexes, and possible respiratory distress.  Guillain-Barré is not typically associated with fever or altered mental status at the time of symptom onset.
  • Enteroviruses:  Commonly cause viral meningitis in the summer and early fall and present with severe headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, and low-grade fever.  However, enteroviral meningitis does not usually cause mental status changes or Parkinsonian symptoms.
  • Poliovirus:  Can cause acute flaccid paralysis from dysfunctional anterior horn cells similar to Japanese encephalitis.  However, polio does not usually present with fever, mental status changes, headache, or seizures.

Management



There is no specific antiviral treatment for Japanese encephalitis.  Management is supportive and includes:



  • Seizure control with antiseizure medications.
  • Monitoring and management of increased intracranial pressure.
  • Respiratory support if brainstem involvement or coma is present.
  • Physical and occupational therapy for rehabilitation in survivors.

Prognosis



The prognosis of Japanese encephalitis varies by age, immune status, and disease severity.  The mortality rate for neuroinvasive disease ranges from 20 to 30%.  Among survivors, ~30% are left with significant long-term neurologic sequelae, including cognitive impairment, motor deficits, extrapyramidal symptoms, behavioral changes, and/or seizures.

Prevention



Prevention is key to decreasing infection rates and includes:



  • Vaccination, which is recommended for individuals in endemic areas and travelers at risk (eg, longer travel, time in rural areas, outdoor activities).  Childhood vaccination programs in endemic areas have dramatically reduced cases of Japanese encephalitis.
  • Mosquito control measures (eg, nets, elimination of breeding sites).
  • Protective clothing and insect repellent during seasons of peak mosquito activity.

Summary



Japanese encephalitis is a potentially severe viral encephalitis endemic to parts of Asia and the western Pacific.  Although most infections are asymptomatic, some cases progress to severe encephalitis with mental status changes, focal neurologic deficits, seizures, and Parkinsonian symptoms.  Patients with encephalitis can have significant morbidity and mortality.  Diagnosis is usually confirmed by Japanese encephalitis virus–specific IgM antibodies in the CSF.  There is no specific antiviral therapy, so management remains supportive.  Prevention through vaccination and mosquito control measures is key to reducing disease burden.
